text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
Editorial changes are made throughout to update IRM/statute/organizational references and to make the text easier to follow and use electronically.
) IRM

- Revised the title to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the communicated in this subsection. Included important information to conform to the new internal and management control standards under the following titles: a. IRM
, Background - Added background information on the disclosure to foreign countries pursuant to tax treaties. Information from prior IRM
, General, was incorporated into this section. b. IRM
, Authority - Added legal authorities governing Disclosure to Foreign Countries Pursuant to Tax Treaties. c. IRM
, Roles and Responsibilities - This IRM applies to all IRS personnel providing records under the provisions of IRM
d. IRM
, Deﬁnitions/Acronyms - Compiled a list of frequently used terms and abbreviations and their deﬁnitions regarding Disclosure to Foreign Countries Pursuant to Tax Treaties. (
) Removed references to Deputy Commissioner, (International) and replaced with LB&I or Director, Treaty and Transfer Pricing Operations (TTPO) where appropriate. (
) Added new (
) to IRM
, Information Received from Foreign Tax Authorities, to reﬂect disclosures of automatic exchanges of information. Subsequent paragraphs were renumbered accordingly.
a. IRM
, Background - Added background information on the disclosure to foreign countries pursuant to tax treaties. Information from prior IRM
, General, was incorporated into this section. b. IRM

d. IRM
, Deﬁnitions/Acronyms - Compiled a list of frequently used terms and abbreviations and their deﬁnitions regarding Disclosure to Foreign Countries Pursuant to Tax Treaties.

Deleted term “often” from IRM 11.3.25.2(8) Note, since treaty information should always be
All Operating Divisions and Functions.
RELATED RESOURCES
to Foreign Countries Pursuant to Tax 11.3.25

) Purpose: Disclosures of information to, or received from, foreign tax are governed by tax treaties, tax information exchange agreements (TIEAs), and provisions of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC), and in some cases, Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) intergovernmental agreements. This section provides instructions concerning Disclosure to Foreign Countries Pursuant to Tax Treaties, TIEAs and the IRC. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to all IRS employees and contractors. (
) Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, and Safeguards (GLDS), is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (

) Program Owner: The GLDS office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison Disclosure (PGLD), is the program office responsible for coordination of the Servicewide Disclosure policy with Large Business and International (LB&I). (

) Primary Stakeholders: The following offices within LB&I have responsibility Disclosures to foreign countries pursuant to tax treaties and TIEAs: • Director, Treaty Administration under the Director, Treaty & Transfer Pricing Operations (TTPO) • Assistant Deputy Commissioner (International) • In addition, legal issues arising with respect to disclosure of to, or received from, foreign tax authorities are within the jurisdiction of Associate Chief Counsel (International), Branch

) Most tax treaties entered into by the United States include provisions governing the exchange of information with the treaty partner. The may relate to income, estate and gift, excise, and other taxes, depending the terms of the particular treaty. TIEAs may also be in effect between the United States and other jurisdictions to authorize the exchange of tax tion. (
) Returns and return information (referred to in this section collectively as “tax information”), as deﬁned in IRC §
, are conﬁdential under the statute cannot be disclosed unless authorized by the IRC. (
) IRC §
) provides an exception for disclosure of tax information to foreign tax authorities pursuant to a treaty or bilateral agreement. IRC §
) provides:
Primary Stakeholders: The following offices within LB&I have responsibility for Disclosures to foreign countries pursuant to tax treaties and TIEAs:

Director, Treaty Administration under the Director, Treaty & Transfer Pricing Operations (TTPO) Assistant Deputy Commissioner (International) In addition, legal issues arising with respect to disclosure of information to, or received from, foreign tax authorities are within the subject-matter jurisdiction of Associate Chief Counsel (International), Branch

) Most tax treaties entered into by the United States include provisions governing the exchange of information with the treaty partner. The information may relate to income, estate and gift, excise, and other taxes, depending on the terms of the particular treaty. TIEAs may also be in effect between the United States and other jurisdictions to authorize the exchange of tax informa- tion. (
) Returns and return information (referred to in this section collectively as “tax information”), as deﬁned in IRC §
, are conﬁdential under the statute and cannot be disclosed unless authorized by the IRC. (
) IRC §
) provides an exception for disclosure of tax information to foreign tax authorities pursuant to a treaty or bilateral agreement. Speciﬁcally, IRC §
) provides:

A return or return information may be disclosed to a competent authority of a foreign government which has an income tax or gift and estate tax convention, or other convention or bilateral agreement relating to the exchange of tax with the United States but only to the extent provided in, and subject to the terms and conditions of, such convention or bilateral agreement.
IRC §

provides that “tax convention information,” or tax treaty information, is conﬁdential and may not be disclosed unless an exception applies. Tax treaty information generally includes information that the IRS receives from a foreign tax authority pursuant to a tax treaty or TIEA. It can also include infor- mation that reﬂects information received from a foreign tax authority, e.g., an

IRC §6105 provides that “tax convention information,” or tax treaty information, is conﬁdential and may not be disclosed unless an exception applies. Tax treaty information generally includes information that the IRS receives from a foreign tax authority pursuant to a tax treaty or TIEA. It can also include infor- mation that reﬂects information received from a foreign tax authority, e.g., an
Disclosure of Official outbound communication that references an inbound communication or from which a speciﬁc issue or matter can be associated with the particular treaty partner. (
) IRC §

(b) provides the following exceptions to the prohibition on of tax treaty information: a. Information may be disclosed to persons or authorities (including courts and administrative bodies) that are entitled to such disclosures under the relevant treaty or agreement. Note: Tax treaties typically impose two conditions for disclosure. First, disclosure must not be prohibited under domestic law such as IRC §

Second, the person to whom the information is disclosed must be involved in the assessment, collection or administration the enforcement or prosecution in respect of, or the determination of appeals in relation to, the taxes covered by the treaty. b. Information may be disclosed as provided under applicable procedures relating to applications for relief under a tax treaty. See Rev. Proc.

, Procedures for Requesting Competent Authority Assistance Under Treaties. c. With the consent of the foreign tax authority, information may be to Federal, state, and local enforcement officers and employees who are directly involved in responding to or investigating any terrorist incident, threat, or activity. d. The Secretary may disclose information that does not relate to a taxpayer if the Secretary determines, after consultation with the relevant treaty partner, that the disclosure would not impair tax administration. (

) Tax treaties and TIEAs provide that the exchange of information between countries be made through each country’s designated Competent Authority. The U.S. Competent Authority under tax treaties and TIEAs is the LB&I Com- missioner. See Delegation Order
, published at IRM

) The United States also has entered into various agreements with its territories (the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands) that include provisions for the exchange of information. Such agreements (e.g., Tax Imple- mentation Agreements, Tax Coordination Agreements, Memorandums of Understanding (MOUs)) with the U.S. territories are among the “Fe
tate” agreements authorized under IRC §
(d). Exchange of information under these Fe
tate agreements with U.S. territories also must be made through the LB&I Commissioner. See Delegation Order
, published at IRM
) Although U.S. territories are considered “states” for purposes of disclosure pursuant to Fe
tate agreements under IRC §
(d), such agreements with U.S. territories are “tax conventions,” or tax treaties, within the meaning of §
As a result, information received by the IRS under Fe
tate agree- ments with U.S. territories may only be disclosed to the extent provided for in the agreements or in the circumstances described in IRC §
and this section.

to Foreign Countries Pursuant to Tax 11.3.25
The following items govern the authority pertaining to disclosures to foreign countries pursuant to tax treaties and TIEAs:
The following is a list of the acronyms that are used in this IRM section:

Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition EOI Exchange of Information FATCA Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act GLDS Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards IRC Internal Revenue Code JITSIC Joint International Taskforce on Shared Intelligence and Collabo- ration LB&I Large Business and International MCAP Mutual Collection Assistance Program MLAT Mutual legal assistance treaty MOU Memorandum of Understanding PGLD Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure TIEA Tax information exchange agreement TTPO Treaty & Transfer Pricing Operations
) If the IRS needs information from a country with which the United States has a tax treaty or TIEA, a request is submitted in accordance with established pro- cedures. (
) IRS employees are to be guided by the provisions of IRM
, International Procedures - Exchange of Information, in requesting information from foreign countries. LB&I staff (Exchange of Information Teams or Joint International
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

Taskforce on Shared Intelligence and Collaboration (JITSIC)) generally the request and, as appropriate, prepares a letter of request for the of the LB&I Commissioner, to be sent to the foreign tax authority. (

) For spontaneous exchanges of information, LB&I Commissioner, LB&I staff (Exchange of Information Teams or JITSIC), will forward information from the treaty partner to the ﬁeld office with jurisdiction over the taxpayer. (

) For automatic exchanges of information, LB&I Commissioner, LB&I staff (Exchange of Information Teams or JITSIC), will make information received from the treaty partner available to the ﬁeld office with jurisdiction over the taxpayer under procedures established by the LB&I Commissioner. (
) Under tax treaties and TIEAs, in conjunction with IRC §
(a), tax treaty formation received by the IRS from a foreign tax authority must be kept conﬁdential unless an exception applies. See IRM

) Because of the requirement to keep tax treaty information conﬁdential, tax treaty information generally may not be disclosed to: • State tax agencies; • The Department of Justice for purposes other than Federal tax tration; or • Other Federal agencies for purposes other than Federal tax tion, even where such disclosure would be authorized for purpose of IRC §

) The U.S.-Mexico and U.S.-Canada tax treaties provide that information exchanged under the treaties may be shared with state and local authorities. a. Pursuant to these treaties, States may be permitted access to tax treaty information received from the relevant foreign tax authority. b. Information received by the LB&I Commissioner, or from the foreign tax authority of these countries may be sent directly to State tax agencies under IRC §
(d). Note: This information is considered Federal tax information and its use is governed by the terms of the tax treaty and Basic Agreement. See IRM
, Disclosure to State and Local Governments, for a discussion on Basic Agreements between the States and IRS. (

) Disclosure staff should ensure that information disclosed for purposes other than Federal tax administration purposes is reviewed and tax treaty is removed prior to disclosure. Note: Information obtained under a tax treaty is stamped to indicate that it is tax treaty information. (
) Information obtained from a foreign tax authority pursuant to a tax treaty or TIEA may be disclosed to the U.S. taxpayer to whom it relates, upon written request from the taxpayer, under IRC §
(e), (see IRM

, Disclosure Persons with a Material Interest). In this situation, the taxpayer is considered be concerned with assessment, collection, enforcement, or prosecution with respect to the taxes that are the subject of the tax treaty or TIEA.

Taskforce on Shared Intelligence and Collaboration (JITSIC)) generally reviews the request and, as appropriate, prepares a letter of request for the signature of the LB&I Commissioner, to be sent to the foreign tax authority.

For automatic exchanges of information, LB&I Commissioner, LB&I staff (Exchange of Information Teams or JITSIC), will make information from the treaty partner available to the ﬁeld office with jurisdiction over the taxpayer under procedures established by the LB&I Commissioner. to Foreign Countries Pursuant to Tax 11.3.25

a. In a case that is not in litigation, the office of Treaty Administration under the Director, Treaty and Transfer Pricing Operations (TTPO), must be contacted prior to disclosure of this information. b. In a case in litigation, disclosure of such information must be coordinated with Associate Chief Counsel (International), Branch
The office of Treaty Administration under the Director, TTPO, has the ﬁnal authority to approve disclosure of information exchanged under a tax treaty or TIEA.
Note: The office of Treaty Administration under the Director, TTPO, has the ﬁnal authority to approve disclosure of information exchanged under a tax treaty

Exception: Disclosure generally will not be made to the taxpayer if the foreign tax authority providing the information objects to disclosure or if the IRS determines that disclosure would seriously impair Federal tax adminis- tration. See IRC §6103(e)(7) and IRM 11.3.2, Disclosure to Persons
tration. See IRC §
) and IRM

) If a Freedom of Information Act request for tax treaty information is follow procedures in IRM
, Freedom of Information Act. (

) If information is needed by a foreign country with which the United States a tax treaty or TIEA, a request is submitted by the foreign competent to the LB&I Commissioner as the U.S. Competent Authority. (
) Disclosure of information by the IRS to foreign tax authorities must be rized by the LB&I Commissioner. (

) Certain automatic or “routine” exchanges (such as transmission of reports taxes withheld from income paid to nonresident aliens) are handled the LB&I Staff (Automatic Exchange of Information Teams). (
) The LB&I Commissioner, generally forwards requests for information to LB&I Program Manager, Exchange of Information or JITSIC. (

) When the requested information is received from the IRS offices, the Commissioner, LB&I staff (Exchange of Information Teams, or JITSIC) prepares a document for the transmittal of the information to the foreign competent authority. For requests pertaining to the Simultaneous Criminal vestigation Program, the LB&I Commissioner, has the authority to any disclosures. (

) For treaty partner requests pertaining to the Simultaneous Examination Program or Industry-wide Exchange of Information, the LB&I will: a. Forward the request to the manager with jurisdiction over the or the relevant International Referral Recipient for action; and b. When the information is received, transmit it to the treaty partner competent authority. (
) For Spontaneous Exchanges of Information, the LB&I Commissioner, staff, (Exchange of Information Teams, or JITSIC), will transmit formation to the treaty partner competent authority. (
) Generally, complete tax returns are not furnished to foreign tax authorities pursuant to tax treaties.
If a Freedom of Information Act request for tax treaty information is received, follow procedures in IRM 11.3.13, Freedom of Information Act.
(07-23-2015) Disclosure of Information to Foreign Tax Authorities
The LB&I Commissioner, generally forwards requests for information to the LB&I Program Manager, Exchange of Information or JITSIC.
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

) If it should become necessary to issue a summons to obtain the requested formation, the summons will be prepared for the staff of the LB&I Commissioner, and forwarded to Associate Chief Counsel (International), Branch
, for review prior to issuance, if necessary. (
) Return information that may potentially identify a conﬁdential informant or otherwise seriously impair an IRS tax investigation is generally not foreign tax authorities. (
) Information which would reveal business or trade secrets is excepted from exchange of information provisions of the treaties. See IRM
, tations on Exchange of Information-Trade Secrets, for further procedures. (
) Disclosures to foreign tax authorities made pursuant to tax treaties must be accounted for in accordance with IRC §
) and the Privacy Act of See IRM
, Accounting for Disclosures, for further information. (
) Information disclosed to U.S. territories under Fe
tate agreements is governed by IRC §
Tax information disclosed pursuant to these agree- ments under IRC §
(d) is also subject to the administrative provisions of IRC §
) and IRC §
). Unauthorized disclosures and tions of tax information exchanged pursuant to Fe
tate agreements with territories may result in criminal sanctions under IRC §
and IRC and civil damages under IRC §
) Although IRC §
) generally provides the authority for disclosure of information to foreign tax authorities, other provisions of IRC §

permit Disclosures to limited disclosures to foreign countries or individuals of foreign countries in Countries certain situations. These disclosures can be made regardless of whether United States has a tax treaty or TIEA with the country. However, when a treaty or TIEA is in force, information must be exchanged under the tax or TIEA to the extent possible. (
) Return information may be disclosed by IRS employees to individuals of foreign countries in accordance with IRC §
). See IRM
, tigative Disclosure. (
) Returns and return information may also be disclosed to individuals of countries designated in writing by a U. S. taxpayer to receive such under IRC §
(c) and (e). (See IRM
, Disclosure to Persons with a Material Interest, and IRM

, Disclosure to Designees and Example: Pursuant to a written taxpayer request and consent for disclosure, may certify to a tax treaty partner that taxes were paid in the United States to enable the taxpayer to receive a credit for the taxes on a foreign return.

Example: Pursuant to a written taxpayer request and consent for disclosure, IRS may certify to a tax treaty partner that taxes were paid in the United States to enable the taxpayer to receive a credit for the taxes on a foreign return.

) The United States and ﬁve of its treaty partners assist each other in the collec- tion of taxes covered by their respective tax treaties. This program is referred to as the Mutual Collection Assistance Program (MCAP) and falls within the scope of the Mutual Assistance Article of the tax treaties in question. The ﬁve countries that participate in the MCAP with the U.S. are:
to Foreign Countries Pursuant to Tax 11.3.25
• Denmark • Sweden • The Netherlands (

) Under MCAP, a requested country will endeavor to collect taxes owed to requesting country by a citizen of the requesting country who is residing in requested country. Such data as name, address, identiﬁcation number, type tax, amount of tax and any other information deemed necessary to assist collection process is exchanged with the participating treaty partner. (
) The authority to sign for matters relating to MCAP has been delegated to Exchange of Information (EOI) Program Manager and those officially acting the EOI Program Manager. See Delegation Order
, published at IRM
The same disclosure provisions apply to exchanges made to MCAP as apply to other exchanges of information made under the tax treaties.
) For a summary of the procedures for processing the requests for (
) (e.g., providing tax returns and tax return information) under the various Mutual Legal Assistance treaties on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters (MLATs), see IRM Treaty Requests
, Disclosures Based on a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty Request in Criminal Matters.
) All disclosures of returns or return information to foreign governments (
) IRC §
) must be accounted for under IRC §
) using Form Accounting for

-B, Multiple Records of Disclosure. The business unit or function Disclosures the disclosure of tax information is responsible for completing the form and warding it to the appropriate Campus for input. Treaty disclosures made by Philadelphia Campus are handled in accordance with the speciﬁc program cedures. See IRM
, Recordkeeping and Accounting for Disclosures, the information required to be included on Form

Under MCAP, a requested country will endeavor to collect taxes owed to the requesting country by a citizen of the requesting country who is residing in the requested country. Such data as name, address, identiﬁcation number, type of tax, amount of tax and any other information deemed necessary to assist the collection process is exchanged with the participating treaty partner.
